objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to propose HypoChainer, a collaborative visualization framework that integrates human expertise, LLM-driven reasoning, and knowledge graphs to enhance scientific discovery visually.
objective.evidence: To address these challenges, we propose HypoChainer, a collaborative visualization framework that integrates human expertise, LLM-driven reasoning, and knowledge graphs (KGs) to enhance scientific discovery visually.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the challenge of integrating human expertise, LLM-driven reasoning, and KG-structured knowledge into a unified hypothesis-driven framework to streamline the discovery of novel mechanisms.
knowledge_gap.evidence: To leverage the complementary strengths and mitigate the limitations of existing methods (LLMs, KGs, and manual workflows), we focus on a critical challenge: integrating human expertise, LLM-driven reasoning, and KG-structured knowledge into a unified hypothesis-driven framework that breaks information silos and streamlines the discovery of novel mechanisms.

answer: The integration of LLMs and KGs into a collaborative framework for hypothesis-driven scientific discovery.
The development of a visualization framework that supports hypothesis construction and validation through interactive exploration.
The use of hypothesis chains to structure reasoning paths composed of multiple interrelated hypotheses.
evidence: We propose a collaborative framework that synergizes human intuition, LLMs, and KGs through the construction of hypothesis chains—structured reasoning paths composed of multiple interrelated hypotheses connected by logical links.

We developed a collaborative framework, HypoChainer, linking LLMs and KGs, enabling experts to explore model predictions, construct and refine hypothesis chains, uncover underlying mechanisms, and prioritize validations through interactive visualization.

steps.input: Domain experts raise research questions, prompting a retrieval-augmented LLM (RAG) to surface relevant research objects from GNN predictions.
steps.output: Interactive visualizations and LLM-generated explanations contextualize results, enabling experts to better analyze predictions.

tools.name: GraphSAGE
tools.description: Used to generate node embeddings by leveraging structural and attribute information from PubMedBERT.
tools.evidence: KGML-xDTD [41] is a drug repurposing prediction and mechanism of action (MOA) inference model, integrating graph-based learning with reinforcement learning. The module formulates the task as a link prediction problem, which employs GraphSAGE, to generate node embeddings by leveraging structural and attribute information from PubMedBERT.

tools.name: LightRAG
tools.description: Used for integrating reasoning models and retrieval mechanisms to synchronize KG data, AI-generated insights, and expert input.
tools.evidence: The ChatBot (Fig. 1- B ) serves as the central hub of the system, orchestrating seamless interactions across all interface components by integrating reasoning models (LLM) and retrieval mechanisms, which is based on LightRAG [19] for its lower cost and faster response compared to GraphRAG [15] (RAG), to synchronize KG data, AI-generated insights, and expert input.

benchmark_datasets.name: SynLethDB
benchmark_datasets.usage: Used for constructing the cancer research knowledge graph.
benchmark_datasets.evidence: Cancer Research. This dataset [72] focuses on SL relationships, where the simultaneous inactivation of a gene pair leads to the death of a specific cancer cell. The cancer research knowledge graph is constructed using data from two primary repositories: SynLethDB, which catalogs validated gene SL interactions, and ProteinKG25, a biomedical knowledge dataset containing information on gene functions, pathways, and biological processes.
